node.title: Feature/fix reload
node.body:

* プレビュー中のファイルの変更を画面に反映させるように修正

## Scope of Influenced

* .mainProcess.js

### Work

* 2023/06/10

node.bodyText: レビューを終了

node.title: quizy用の各テーブルのmigrationファイルとmodel作成
node.body:
以下のようにテーブル設計しました。

テーブル: 問題 (questions)
　カラム: question_id (主キー)
　カラム: question_text (問題のテキスト)

テーブル: 選択肢 (options)
　カラム: option_id (主キー)
　カラム: option_question_id (外部キー - 問題テーブルの question_id と関連付け)
　カラム: option_text (選択肢のテキスト)

テーブル: 正解 (Answers)
　カラム: answer_id (主キー)
　カラム: answer_question_id (外部キー - 問題テーブルの question_id と関連付け)
　カラム: answer_option_id (外部キー - 選択肢テーブルの option_id と関連付け)

node.bodyText:
resourceコントローラーの方が使いやすいよ
https://readouble.com/laravel/8.x/ja/controllers.html

主キーはカラム名idにする
https://readouble.com/laravel/master/ja/migrations.html
カラム名textでいい

物理削除ならこのままでいいけど論理削除なら以下のリンク参考にして
https://php-junkie.net/framework/laravel/soft-delete/
questionsテーブルと同様

外部キー制約つけよう
https://zenn.dev/msksgm/articles/20211105-larvale8-migrate-foreign-key
answersテーブルつくるよりかはoptionsテーブルにvalidカラム付けた方がいいんじゃないかな？

論理削除つかうなら
https://e-seventh.com/laravel-softdelete-1/

論理削除つかうなら
https://e-seventh.com/laravel-softdelete-1/
answersテーブルなくすならこのモデル不要

optionとのリレーション書こう
https://readouble.com/laravel/8.x/ja/eloquent-relationships.html

questionとのリレーション書こう
https://readouble.com/laravel/8.x/ja/eloquent-relationships.html
微修正したらオッケーだと思う
わざわざ新しく書く必要はなくて、14~18の中に書いちゃって大丈夫
questions同様

classの外でもsoftdeleteの宣言しなくて大丈夫かな？
今はエラー起きないかもだけど削除するときにエラー起きると思う
option同様

18~42全部いらないかな
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\SoftDeletes;
をクラスの外に書いておくだけで十分
試しに論理削除してみ。deleted_atとupdated_atに自動で日付情報入ってるはず
option同様

コントローラー内にこのメソッドはいらないかな
一度しか使わないならindexに直接書いていいし
複数回使うならモデルに書いてほしいかな
第二引数compactメソッド使った方が楽だよ

findOrFailの方がいいかな
見つからなかったらredirectとかもできるね

削除完了時にflush message出ると親切だね
https://chat.openai.com/share/2c48e39c-2444-4a80-8d9f-3aa2a56add59
ここにもflash messageほしいかな
選択肢の数変動できるような設計だとより良いね
選択肢の数変動できるような設計だとより良いね

たぶん'first'-1とかになるね
数か月後に見たときになんで-1してるのか瞬時に思い出せないと思うからマジックナンバーはできるだけ使わない方がいいかな
この中身はstoreメソッドに書こう

37~45はresourceで呼ぼう
https://readouble.com/laravel/8.x/ja/controllers.html

static functionでいいかな
return self::with()->get();
選択肢の数関係なく対応できてていいね

https://chat.openai.com/share/dc1c3fcf-0414-4089-ae4e-9265f0a49583
フロントこんな感じにしてほしい（リンクの一番下）
バックエンドでこれらを受け取ってクイズ作れるようにしてほしい
フロントに対応させてほしい
微修正で完璧！

inputにrequiredつけよう
labelに赤い米印あると親切だね
選択肢も同様

nodes.bodyText:
there is also a linking issue I needed to workaround when llvm is compiled to not split libs:
llvm/llvm-project#34593

Thanks! I will need to study what native means. I would think we need it, but maybe not. What does the
    if (NOT TARGET LLVMCore)
        set (llvm_libs "LLVM")
    endif ()
part do?

it checks if llvm is compiled into a single libLLVM library or into separate libs: libLLVMCore, ...
on archlinux llvm is built with LLVM_LINK_LLVM_DYLIB which cause it to have a single libLLVM lib
looks I did not break anything :)

node.bodyText:
Is this an accurate description of the logic here?
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                # workaround for https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/34593
          
          
            
                # Workaround for https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/34593
          
          
            
                # If LLVM is distributed as a single library (the LLVMCore target is missing), we set `llvm_libs` to "LLVM" which links against the single `libLLVM.so` shared library.

What is the purpose of this change? Is it still needed? It looks like you override it below by setting llvm_libs=LLVM anyway.
What does the native component do? I wasn't able to find it easily using google but chatgpt says this: https://chat.openai.com/share/02f016be-45f2-46f9-8709-65da1b982762, so it seems this component does the target machine native code generation. I think we need this component.

yes, I could completely bypass it
seems "native" is not needed after all since the detection goes fine one other platforms on the CI

Yes, it seems at least at a CI native is not needed.
On your machine, does the build now work with native included? If not, what is the error message?

with "native" cmake failed with : Target X86 is not in the set of libraries
then I had to fixed llvm_libs names for the linking failed
I see. Can you try this PR and see if it fixes this issue on your machine: #1791 ?
yes, it works, I close my PR
It also seems that linking to "LLVM" works even when LLMCore target is available

node.title: metal : faster q40
node.body:
For a run with 256 tokens prediction time is now 23 ms / token on my 30-core M2 Mac GPU, down from 27 ms/token.

Avoiding a local copies to `float4` and `uchar4` brings ~8% speedup, using 64 threads per thread group in an 8x8 arrangement brings another 9%.

Memory throughput is now ~270 GB/s, so ~90% of theoretical limit.

nodes.bodyText: On an 38-core M2 Max, 65B q4_0, this PR takes it from 189ms to 154ms per token (22% improvement)

Congratulations on your accomplishments!
I'm curious, have you tried inputting code into GPT-4 and requesting optimization, such as memory copying or matrix computation? Would it be able to generate an optimized code that is functional?
FYI:
https://twitter.com/DimitrisPapail/status/1666843952824168465
@shouyiwang No, I haven't tried using GPT-4. Have you? Perhaps you could ask GPT-4 to optimize this kernel?
Just let me know if I need further follow up questions.

@shouyiwang I was hoping GPT-4 will re-write the kernel for us ;-)
The comments it is making are very generic. Even I know all of this, despite being a total beginner when it comes to programming for Metal with this being the very first thing I ever did on this platform. It did not notice the branch, which comes with a heavy penalty, and is there not because I don't know that it is better to not have branches, but because I hadn't seen how to avoid it. I have a better version now that executes in 25.3 ms/token (down from 28.3 ms/token), see 694af8a

@shouyiwang This is great! It speeds up the calculation by 0.3%. But for this part of the kernel there is a better way that uses thread group operations (quad_shuffle_xor and such). With me being a beginner, I haven't been able to make it work that way.
The branch I was referring to in my previous post was in the function get_scale_min_k4(). This was the costly branch that speeds things up by 10% when removed.
So, shall I stop looking for Metal developers and just buy GPT-4 subscription? 😄

@ikawrakow I realized that the reason GPT4 didn't detect the branch problem was because I had not included the get_scale_min_k4() function in the context. After adding it, GPT4 quickly identified the problem and provided an alternative implementation. I hope this updated information is helpful.
https://chat.openai.com/share/aeda3bfa-4723-4ac0-9ca4-905be6066f4f

So, shall I stop looking for Metal developers and just buy GPT-4 subscription? 😄

HAHAHA
I think you should do both: recruit more Metal developers and buy them GPT-4 subscriptions :)

node.bodyText:
Amazing stuff! 🦙
Would be interesting to benchmark this on 38-core M2 Max GPU as well
